key_points: The government dismissed federal charges against Marimar Martinez after significant concerns were raised about the handling of key evidence and the credibility of the Border Patrol agent's testimony.

Text messages showing the agent bragging about shooting Martinez, including claims of 'five shots, seven holes,' raised serious ethical and legal concerns about the agent's actions and potential bias.

The Border Patrol agent's SUV was moved 1,000 miles from Chicago to Maine, where it may have been repaired, raising serious questions about the preservation of physical evidence and undermining the integrity of the investigation.

canonical_title: Superman #1 copy found in attic becomes most expensive comic ever sold

members.title: Superman #1 copy found in attic becomes most expensive comic ever sold
key_points: A copy of Superman #1, discovered in a California attic, sold for $9.12 million at Heritage Auctions, making it the most expensive comic ever sold.

The comic was found by three brothers in northern California while clearing out their mother’s attic after her death, with the family having inherited the collection from her brother during the Great Depression.
The comic was part of DC's first print run of half a million copies and is considered the highest ever graded copy due to its exceptional preservation.

canonical_title: Invest in crypto? Here’s what to know about your 2025 taxes

members.title: Invest in crypto? Here’s what to know about your 2025 taxes
key_points: Investors using centralized exchanges (e.g., Coinbase) will receive a Form 1099-DA by February 17, 2026, detailing gross proceeds from crypto sales, but not cost basis.
The 1099-DA does not create new tax obligations, but helps the IRS identify discrepancies between self-reported income and exchange-reported data, potentially triggering an automated notice.
Cost basis — essential for calculating capital gains and losses — will not be reported on the 1099-DA in 2025; it must be tracked by the investor personally.

members.title: Polar Vortex Disruption on the Way in November: One of the Earliest and Most Significant Since Satellite Era Began
key_points: A sudden stratospheric warming event is occurring in the upper atmosphere above the North Pole, causing the polar vortex to weaken and potentially reverse.
This is one of the earliest and most significant polar vortex disruptions recorded since satellite observations began, with such events being almost unheard of in November.
The weakening polar vortex could result in cold, snowy conditions across parts of the US, Europe, and Asia, especially in mid-latitudes where most of the world's population lives.

Despite government moves toward metal scaffolding for safety and standardization, bamboo remains dominant — currently used in about 80% of scaffolds, often in hybrid systems with steel.

members.title: RFK Jr walks back Trump administration’s claims linking Tylenol and autism
key_points: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has partially retracted his earlier, unsubstantiated claim that Tylenol use during pregnancy causes autism, stating that while there is a suggestive association, it is not sufficient to conclude a causal link.

The World Health Organization and major health agencies have consistently stated there is no consistent or conclusive evidence linking Tylenol to autism, emphasizing the importance of medical consultation during pregnancy.

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed a lawsuit against Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, accusing them of deceptive marketing of Tylenol as the only safe painkiller for pregnant women, citing claims made by President Trump and Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

key_points: China perceives Japan’s new Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi’s comments on military intervention in Taiwan as a direct challenge to its national sovereignty and a revival of Japan’s militarism.

China has responded with economic pressure, nationalist propaganda, and military symbolism, signaling a clear warning to Japan and other regional powers about the risks of opposing Beijing’s position on Taiwan.

The historical trauma of Japan’s imperial occupation of China and Taiwan, especially the Nanjing Massacre, fuels deep anti-Japanese sentiment in China and underpins Beijing’s narrative of resistance to Japanese militarism.

canonical_title: Frida Kahlo painting sells for $54.7m, breaking record for female artists

members.title: Frida Kahlo painting sells for $54.7m, breaking record for female artists
key_points: Frida Kahlo’s 'El sueño (La cama)' sold for $54.7 million at Sotheby’s in New York, becoming the most expensive work by a female artist ever sold at auction.
The sale surpassed Georgia O’Keeffe’s 2014 record of $44.4 million and also broke Kahlo’s own previous auction record as a Latin American artist.
The painting, painted in 1940, is one of only a few Kahlo works to remain in private hands outside Mexico, where her works are protected by law from export or destruction.

key_points: The US Navy is attempting to recover two crashed aircraft — an F/A-18 Super Hornet and an MH-60 helicopter — from the South China Sea floor after they crashed within 30 minutes of each other during routine operations off the USS Nimitz.
The crashes occurred in late October 2025; no official cause has been confirmed, though President Donald Trump suggested contaminated fuel may be responsible.
The US Navy deployed the USNS SALVOR (T-ARS 52), a Safeguard-class salvage ship, to conduct recovery operations; the ship is capable of lifting objects up to 300 tons.

members.title: India wants COP30 to focus on climate adaptation, but dries up own fund
key_points: India faces one of the world’s largest climate displacement crises, with over 32 million people displaced between 2015 and 2024.
Despite advocating for climate adaptation at COP30, India’s National Adaptation Fund for Climate Change (NAFCC) has been financially dried up since 2023, with zero funding allocated in 2023–2024.
The NAFCC, launched in 2015 to fund climate-resilient projects in agriculture, water management, and infrastructure, has not been funded for years, halting critical adaptation projects.

key_points: The U.S. cancer registries, which collect and analyze data on cancer incidence and survival, are being required to classify patients' sex only as male, female, or unknown, due to Trump administration policies.
This change excludes transgender and non-binary individuals from being properly represented in national cancer data, undermining efforts to study health disparities among transgender populations.
Transgender people are more likely to use tobacco and less likely to receive routine cancer screenings, increasing their risk of cancer — a gap that data collection is critical to addressing.

canonical_title: How long can a Thanksgiving buffet sit out? A doctor explains

members.title: How long can a Thanksgiving buffet sit out? A doctor explains
key_points: Foodborne illnesses are preventable and often caused by pathogens like norovirus, salmonella, E. coli, Campylobacter, and listeria.

The two-hour rule applies to all perishable foods: once cooked, they should not be left out at room temperature for more than two hours; in temperatures above 90°F, refrigeration is needed after one hour.
Safe thawing methods include refrigeration (24 hours per 4–5 lbs), cold water submersion (30 minutes per pound), or microwave use—followed immediately by cooking.

members.title: Fire Prompts Evacuations at U.N. Climate Talks in Brazil; 13 Suffer Smoke Inhalation
key_points: A fire briefly spread through multiple pavilions at the COP30 climate talks in Belem, Brazil, on November 20, 2025, prompting evacuations and leading to 13 people being treated for smoke inhalation.

The fire originated near the China Pavilion and quickly spread to neighboring pavilions, including African and youth-focused pavilions, due to the structure and construction of temporary, flammable canvas pavilions.
Officials suspect the fire may have started from a generator failure or short circuit in a booth, highlighting risks associated with unfinished and poorly insulated construction at the venue.

canonical_title: Wieambilla ambush: Australian police murder not an act of religious terrorism, coroner finds

members.title: Wieambilla ambush: Australian police murder not an act of religious terrorism, coroner finds
key_points: The 2022 Wieambilla ambush was not classified as a terrorist act by Queensland’s coroner, despite initial assumptions, due to the perpetrators' delusional and defensive motivations.

The Trains were identified as religious fanatics and conspiracy theorists, with beliefs rooted in anti-government ideology and end-times prophecy, especially influenced by the 1996 Port Arthur massacre.

The incident revealed significant failures in inter-state communication between NSW and Queensland police, with critical emails from Nathaniel Train’s wife not being shared, which could have prevented the tragedy.

canonical_title: Nathan Gill: How WhatsApp messages revealed ex-Reform politician's pro-Russian bribes

members.title: Nathan Gill: How WhatsApp messages revealed ex-Reform politician's pro-Russian bribes
key_points: Nathan Gill, a former UKIP and Brexit Party MEP, admitted to eight counts of bribery for promoting pro-Russian narratives and supporting Ukrainian TV stations linked to Viktor Medvedchuk, a pro-Russian oligarch with Putin as godfather.

Oleg Voloshyn, a former Ukrainian parliamentarian from a pro-Russian party, acted as a key intermediary in the bribery scheme, using coded WhatsApp messages such as 'Xmas gifts' and 'post cards' to refer to cash payments.

Gill received payments to defend pro-Russian TV channels (112 Ukraine and NewsOne) during parliamentary debates and to host a meeting with Viktor Medvedchuk in Strasbourg, which was broadcast on Kremlin-aligned media.

canonical_title: NCAA Currently Falling Short to Rescind Rule That Would Allow College Athletes to Gamble on Professional Sports, Source Says

members.title: NCAA Currently Falling Short to Rescind Rule That Would Allow College Athletes to Gamble on Professional Sports, Source Says
key_points: The NCAA is facing a critical deadline to rescind a rule allowing college athletes, coaches, and staff to gamble on professional sports, with a threshold of 241 out of 361 Division I schools needed to stop the rule change.
As of Thursday night, 188 Division I schools had submitted requests for rescission, falling short of the required two-thirds (241) to prevent implementation.

The rule change was prompted by the rise in legal sports gambling across 38 U.S. states and growing public and political scrutiny over sports integrity following recent high-profile arrests of professional and college athletes involved in gambling schemes.

members.title: CDC Website Changed to Include False Claims Linking Autism and Vaccines
key_points: The CDC website now includes anti-vaccine talking points that do not rule out a link between vaccines and autism, despite overwhelming scientific evidence showing no such connection.

The updated page states 'vaccines do not cause autism' with a footnote citing a political agreement with U.S. Senate Health Committee chair Bill Cassidy, which may have been influenced by Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s anti-vaccine advocacy.

A major Danish study from 2019, which found no link between MMR vaccines and autism, is not cited on the CDC page, though a 2025 Danish study on aluminum and neurodevelopmental disorders is referenced selectively and with questionable interpretation.

canonical_title: Australia adds Reddit, Kick to social media ban for children under 16

members.title: Australia adds Reddit, Kick to social media ban for children under 16
key_points: Australia will ban children under 16 from accessing social media platforms including Reddit, Kick, Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Threads, TikTok, X, and YouTube, effective December 10, 2025.

The ban is part of a broader online safety initiative led by the eSafety Commissioner, Julie Inman Grant, with the goal of protecting children from harmful design features such as opaque algorithms and endless scrolling.
Platforms were given 12 months to comply, and failure to do so may result in civil fines of up to 49.5 million Australian dollars (US$32.1 million).

canonical_title: James Watson, who co-discovered DNA double helix, dies at 97

members.title: James Watson, who co-discovered DNA double helix, dies at 97
key_points: James Watson, a co-discoverer of the DNA double helix, died at the age of 97, marking the end of a life defined by groundbreaking scientific achievement and significant controversy.
The discovery of DNA’s double helix structure in 1953 revolutionized biology, enabling advances in genetic engineering, medicine, and forensic science.

Watson’s scientific legacy is overshadowed by his promotion of debunked and racist theories, particularly in the 2007 and 2019 statements where he claimed genetic differences between racial groups imply differences in intelligence.

canonical_title: Colombia recovers first treasures from 300-year-old ‘holy grail of shipwrecks’

members.title: Colombia recovers first treasures from 300-year-old ‘holy grail of shipwrecks’
key_points: Colombia has recovered gold, bronze coins, a porcelain cup, and a cannon from the sunken Spanish warship San José, considered the 'holy grail of shipwrecks'.
The shipwreck occurred in 1708 during the War of the Spanish Succession, when the San José was carrying vast amounts of gold, silver, and emeralds from Spanish colonies to Spain.
The recovery is significant for understanding early 18th-century European economic and political climates and for enriching Colombia’s national cultural identity.

members.title: House Moves to Repeal Controversial 'Arctic Frost' Provision That Allows GOP Senators to Seek $500,000 Payouts
key_points: The House unanimously voted 426-0 to repeal a controversial provision allowing senators to sue the Justice Department for up to $500,000 when their phone records are seized without notice.
The provision, part of a government funding bill, was included after Senate Republicans released FBI records from the 'Arctic Frost' investigation into the 2020 fake elector scheme.
The provision requires senators to be notified when federal investigators access their phone records, with exceptions; if not notified, they may sue for damages.

canonical_title: Are astronomers wrong about dark energy? New study casts doubt on universe’s accelerating expansion
entities: Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST)

members.title: Are astronomers wrong about dark energy? New study casts doubt on universe’s accelerating expansion
key_points: The universe's expansion may not be accelerating but could be slowing down, challenging the long-held belief that dark energy drives continuous acceleration.

The new study suggests that the brightness of Type Ia supernovae depends on the age of their progenitor stars — older stars produce brighter supernovae, which could have misled earlier interpretations of cosmic expansion.

This age-brightness correlation could explain why previous supernova observations appeared to show an accelerating universe when, in reality, the dimming might be due to stellar age rather than dark energy.

canonical_title: Transportation Department Endorses Crash Test Dummy That More Closely Resembles Women

members.title: Transportation Department Endorses Crash Test Dummy That More Closely Resembles Women
key_points: Women are 73% more likely to be injured in a head-on crash and 17% more likely to be killed in a car crash than men.
The standard crash test dummy used since 1978 was based on a 5-foot-9, 171-pound male, leading to safety disparities.
The new female crash test dummy is smaller, includes a rubber jacket to represent breasts, and reflects anatomical differences such as neck shape, collarbone, pelvis, and legs.

The magma traveled over 20km horizontally through the Earth's crust, moving through a channel more than 10km beneath the seafloor between Santorini and Anafi.
The volume of magma involved could have filled 200,000 Olympic-sized swimming pools, indicating a significant geological shift.

key_points: Rare earth elements, though not rare in nature, are crucial for modern technologies such as electric vehicles, wind turbines, and medical imaging, and their processing is currently dominated by China, which controls nearly 90% of global refining.

The U.S. has historically struggled to process rare earths due to environmental concerns and outdated methods, especially at the Mountain Pass mine in California, which faced shutdowns and pollution issues.

The U.S. government, under both the Trump and Biden administrations, is investing heavily in rare earth development through public-private partnerships, including loans and ownership stakes in companies like ReElement Technologies and MP Materials.

key_points: Bar Kupershtein, a 23-year-old Israeli security guard, was kidnapped on October 7, 2023, during a Hamas attack at the Nova Festival in Israel.
He spent 738 days in captivity, held in a small underground dungeon by Hamas, during which he endured beatings, starvation, and psychological torture.
Despite the trauma, he maintained his mental strength through faith, humor, and a radio connection to Israeli military broadcasts, which provided updates from home.

canonical_title: US judge orders end to Trump’s deployment of troops in Washington, DC

members.title: US judge orders end to Trump’s deployment of troops in Washington, DC
key_points: A U.S. federal judge ordered the immediate pause of the Trump administration's deployment of National Guard troops to Washington, DC, citing violations of civil liberties and misuse of federal power.

The deployment, which included about 2,300 National Guard members and federal agents, was conducted without declared emergencies and in cities led by Democrats, drawing criticism from local officials and civil rights groups.
The legal challenge alleged that the president had usurped policing powers and used the military for domestic law enforcement, a significant concern for democratic norms and local governance.

canonical_title: Canadian man loses legal battle to keep his secret million-dollar stash

members.title: Canadian man loses legal battle to keep his secret million-dollar stash
key_points: Marcel Breton, a Canadian man, lost a 16-year legal battle to keep over 1.2 million Canadian dollars he buried in unusual locations on his property.
The money was discovered in 2009 during a police search for an illegal handgun, including $15,000 in floor heating ducts, $32,000 in garage locations, and over $1.2 million in a buried rubber tub.

The Ontario appeals court upheld a 2023 ruling that most of the money should be confiscated by the government, citing the unusual nature of the storage, the prevalence of 20-dollar bills (commonly associated with drug trade), and Breton’s lack of reported income from 2001 to 2008.

canonical_title: U.S. Reaches Milestone in Vehicle Safety with New Female Crash Test Dummy

members.title: U.S. Reaches Milestone in Vehicle Safety with New Female Crash Test Dummy
key_points: The U.S. Department of Transportation has released a new crash test dummy designed specifically to represent women, addressing gender-based differences in vehicle crash injury risks.
Women are 73% more likely to be injured and 17% more likely to die in head-on crashes than men, highlighting a critical safety disparity in current vehicle safety testing.
The existing standard crash test dummy, developed in 1978, was based on a 5-foot-9, 171-pound male, leading to underrepresentation of female physiological characteristics in crash testing.

digest_abridged:

canonical_title: Israel plans to seize major Roman-era historical site in occupied West Bank

members.title: Israel plans to seize major Roman-era historical site in occupied West Bank
key_points: Israel plans to seize a major Roman-era archaeological site in Sebastia, located in the occupied West Bank, under a government order released on November 12, 2023.
The site is estimated at 1,800 dunams (180 hectares or 450 acres), making it Israel’s largest seizure of archaeologically significant land according to Peace Now.

The Israeli Civil Administration has designated the northern privately owned lands of Sebastia for expropriation with the goal of developing the site into a tourist attraction, having already allocated over 30 million shekels ($9.24 million) for development.

members.title: Russian envoy Kirill Dmitriev: Putin propagandist or key to peace with Ukraine?
key_points: Kirill Dmitriev is a rare blend of diplomatic and commercial expertise, serving as a key Russian envoy to the US, especially under the Trump administration, and as head of the Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF).

His background includes early exposure to Ukrainian nationalism, anti-Soviet activism as a youth, and extensive study and work in the US, which gives him a unique perspective on both Ukrainian and US political dynamics.
Dmitriev has been accused of being a 'Putin propagandist' by US officials, particularly during the Biden years, due to his role in RDIF and alleged alignment with Kremlin interests.

canonical_title: Appeals Court Blocks Release of Hundreds of Migrants Arrested in Illinois Just a Day Before They Could Have Left Detention

members.title: Appeals Court Blocks Release of Hundreds of Migrants Arrested in Illinois Just a Day Before They Could Have Left Detention
key_points: A federal appeals court blocked the release of hundreds of migrants detained in Illinois just one day before they were scheduled to be released, reversing a lower court's order that had mandated their release on bond.

The arrests were part of Operation Midway Blitz, a nationwide DHS campaign targeting immigrants in the Chicago area, which raised significant concerns over warrantless detentions, racial profiling, and constitutional violations.

Only 16 of the over 600 individuals on the DOJ release list had criminal histories, including convictions for aggravated assault, DUI, battery, and kidnapping, suggesting that the risk assessments were minimal.

canonical_title: Brain Scientists Seek Weight-Loss Drugs Without Nausea

members.title: Brain Scientists Seek Weight-Loss Drugs Without Nausea
key_points: Weight-loss drugs like Wegovy and Zepbound are effective but cause severe nausea and vomiting, leading many patients to discontinue treatment.
Researchers are seeking to modify GLP-1 agonists to suppress appetite without triggering nausea by targeting specific brain regions.

A team led by Warren Yacawych at the University of Michigan found that GLP-1 drugs affect two brain stem areas: one responsible for nausea (vomit center) and one for fullness; separating these effects may allow weight loss without side effects.

digest_abridged:
Scientists aim to redesign GLP-1 drugs to reduce nausea while preserving appetite suppression.

- New focus on brain-region-specific GLP-1 targeting to avoid nausea
- University of Michigan team identified distinct brain stem areas for fullness and nausea

canonical_title: Women’s college soccer team wins conference championship just 3 days after its beloved goalie died
entities: University of Washington women's soccer team

members.title: Women’s college soccer team wins conference championship just 3 days after its beloved goalie died
key_points: The University of Washington women's soccer team won the Big Ten tournament championship just three days after the death of their beloved goalkeeper, Mia Hamant.

Mia Hamant, a senior goalkeeper, died from stage 4 kidney cancer, which she had been fighting since April 2025, and she remained a central emotional and motivational force for the team despite her illness.
The team honored her memory by wearing orange, the color of kidney cancer awareness, and playing her playlist in the locker room during the final match.

members.title: Why has Canada lost its measles-free status – and could the US be next?
key_points: Canada has lost its measles elimination status after a large, multi-jurisdictional outbreak began in October 2024.
The Americas region has lost its elimination status due to the Canadian outbreak, with 95% of cases reported in Canada, Mexico, and the US.
Measles is highly infectious and spreads through respiratory droplets; symptoms include runny nose, fever, red eyes, and a characteristic rash.
